journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Observer-based backstepping control of the half-direct permanent magnet wind power generation system

contrib-group.aff: School of Automation, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu. People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *School of Automation, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu 610041, People’s Republic of China. email: zhenzhenzhang@uestc.edu.cn

abstract.p: In this paper, an observer-based backstepping controller is presented for the half-direct permanent magnet wind power generation system. The technology of backstepping is introduced to design the controller for maximum power point tracking at the operation region with low and moderate wind, and the high-gain observer is designed to estimate the unmeasurable variables needed for the controller design. Moreover, a switching mechanism is proposed, in which an online rotational speed is defined for the startup-to-grid-connected switch of the half-direct permanent magnet wind power generation system. Then, the stability of the designed closed-loop controlled system is analysed, based on the Lyapunov asymptotical stability theory. Simulation results are presented to show the efficiency of the proposed control law.

kwd-group.kwd: half-direct permanent magnet wind power generation system (HDPMWPG)

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: In response to environmental and economical concerns, utilization of wind energy has been increasingly significant effective [1]. A comparative study of past and present generator technologies in wind generation systems has been conducted in reference [2]. Variable-speed generation systems are more attractive for practical use.

Among many variable speed wind generation systems, the doubly fed induction generator equipped with wind generation system is very attractive for high-performance variable-speed drive and generating applications [3–6], due to the main advantage that the power conversion only processes a small fraction of the total system power, approximately
20
per cent. According to the statistical data reported in reference [7], the failure of the troublesome gearbox has contributed for
20
per cent of the wind generation downtime. Thus, the permanent magnet synchronous generator (PMSG) has been introduced for variable-speed wind generation systems, due to its simple structure and low maintenance as a result of removing the gearbox between the wind turbine and the generator [8–10]. However, the problem of heavy bulk and large size is introduced by the high pole number of the PMSG. As a trade-off, the half-direct permanent magnet wind power generation system (HDPMWPGS) is proposed, by adopting a small-ratio gearbox between the wind turbine and the permanent magnet synchronous generator. The small-ratio gearbox not only decreases the bulk and the size of the PMSG by reducing the demand for the number of pole pairs, but also lowers the maintenance by avoiding the fault of the big-ratio gearbox. The HDPMWPGS is more practical in utilization due to its smaller-ratio gearbox and smaller bulk [11]. The control strategy should be investigated for the HDPMWPGS. Little research has been conducted so far.

Over the past decades, there has been tremendous interest in the study of control of variable-speed wind generation systems (VSWGSs). However, control of a VSWGS is not easy, due to the high nonlinearity and the uncertainty, especially the intermittent nature of wind [12]. The control objective depends on the range within which the VSWGS operates. Maximizing the power capture is desired in low and moderate wind input by maintaining the tip-speed ratio at its optimum value, while the output power should be limited at its rated value by reducing the wind power capture when the wind speed is above the rated wind speed.

To extract maximum power from the fluctuating wind, the maximum power point tracking (MPPT) technique was adapted to achieve optimum wind-energy utilization [13–20]. Considerable research has been done on the controller design to maximize the power capture, by regulating the rotational speed to maintain the optimal tip-speed ratio according to the wind velocity measured – for example, the memory-based controller [15], sliding mode controller [16], the high-order sliding-mode controller [17], the adaptive fuzzy controller [18], etc.

This paper focuses on controller design for maximizing the power efficiency of the HDPMWPGS in low and moderate wind, with the control strategy of regulating the rotational speed according to the wind speed. Motivated by the work in references [21] to [25], the technology of backstepping is effective for the rotational speed control of the permanent magnet machine-based system. An observer-based backstepping controller is designed, in which a high-gain observer [26, 27] is introduced to estimate the unmeasurable signal. In addition, a switching mechanism is proposed, in which an online rotational speed is defined for the half-direct permanent magnet wind power generation system to operate from the start-up to the grid-connected state. The main contributions of this paper are as follows.

list-item.p: The backstepping technique is introduced to control the the HDPMWPGS, moderating the rotor speed according to the wind speed to maximize the energy capture in low and moderate wind.
The high-gain observer, along with the extended high-gain observer, estimate the variables needed for the controller design, which are difficult to measure in practice.
The online rational speed is set to switch the HDPMWPGS from the start-up to the grid-connected.
Based on the Lyapunov asymptotical stability theory, the presented control law is proved to render the tracking errors exponentially converge to compact set.

sec.p: This paper is organized as follows. In section 2, the model of the HDPMWPGS is presented. Section 3 proposes the backstepping control system design based on the high-gain observer, and detailed stability analysis is conducted. Finally, simulation studies are shown in section 4 to show the effectiveness of the proposal controller, followed by conclusions in section 5.

sec.title: 2 The Model of the HDPMWPGS
sec.p: As shown in Fig. 1, the HDPMWPGS is modelled and designed in detail in the sequel: wind turbine, driven train, permanent magnet synchronous generation system, and the control system.

The wind turbine is the aerodynamic subsystem of the wind generation system, which converts the wind energy into the mechanical energy. The aerodynamic subsystem is modelled as the mechanical power

sec.title: 4 Simulation Study
sec.p: The simulation study is conducted in Matlab/Simulink based on a 2 MW HDPMWPGS with the parameters shown in Table 1.

sec.p: As shown in Fig. 5 the estimated electrical rotor acceleration of PMSG obtained from the high-gain observer is very close to its true value. The estimated value of the aerodynamic torque, depicted as the solid line in Fig. 6, approximates well to the actual value indicated by the dotted line. The error between the true aerodynamic torque"s first derivative and its estimated value obtained by the high-gain observer is close to zero, which is depicted in Fig. 8.

sec.title: 5 Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, an observer-based controller is presented for the HDPMWPGS. Introducing the virtual input by backstepping technology to design the control inputs, and approximating the unmeasurable signal used in the controller, the rotor speed of the PMSG tracks the desired value, so as to maximize the power capture at low and moderate wind speed. Simulation results show that the proposed control scheme is effective while guaranteeing that the tracking errors exponentially converge to a compact set.
